title: Heavy Rains Batter Nellore and Tirupati Districts in Andhra Pradesh
news:
Heavy rainfall lashed Nellore and Tirupati districts in Andhra Pradesh overnight, causing widespread flooding and disrupting public life. The downpour was triggered by a well-marked low-pressure area that intensified into a depression on Tuesday evening. 

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) reported extremely heavy rainfall in many areas, with Sullurpeta in Tirupati district receiving the highest amount at 220 mm in the 24 hours ending on October 16th.  

The downpour has resulted in significant damage to crops and infrastructure. Over 5,417 hectares of agricultural land across 10 districts have been affected, with Tirupati district bearing the brunt of the damage. Road infrastructure has also been impacted, with at least 261.99 km of roads damaged in several districts. 

The Andhra Pradesh State Disaster Management Authority (APSDMA) reported that 623 people in SPSR Nellore district have been affected by the floods. Relief camps have been set up across the affected districts to accommodate those displaced by the heavy rains. 

A yellow alert has been issued for October 17th, with heavy rain predicted in several districts of Andhra Pradesh. The IMD has also warned that the depression is likely to move towards the north Tamil Nadu-South Andhra Pradesh coast and cross near Chennai in the early hours of October 17th.

title: AIMIM Demands Separate Survey for Muslim Sub-Groups in Telangana
news:
The All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen (AIMIM) has urged the Telangana Backward Classes (BC) Welfare Commission to conduct a separate survey of the BC-E community, encompassing 14 Muslim sub-groups. 

The party, led by former legislator Syed Ahmed Pasha Quadri, argues that a dedicated survey will ensure accurate data collection and proper representation of these communities. These groups, including Attar Saibulu, Achchukattalavandlu, and Faqir, are entitled to 4% reservations under the socially and educationally backward classes.

The AIMIM believes that a separate survey will enable the government to effectively plan socio-economic policies aimed at improving the living conditions of these backward communities. 

The party's Malakpet legislator, Ahmed bin Abdullah Balala, emphasized the importance of accurate data collection and requested the community members to participate actively in the survey. He also stressed that the government should ensure the BC-E community's rightful share of reservations is increased alongside the overall increase in reservations for BCs.

title: Kerala to Host Seminar on 16th Finance Commission
news:
The Gulati Institute of Finance and Taxation (GIFT) and the Kerala Economic Association (KEA) will host a seminar titled "16th Finance Commission and Indian States: A Kerala Perspective" on Friday, October 18th in Thiruvananthapuram, the capital of Kerala. 

The seminar, focusing on the role of the 16th Finance Commission in safeguarding the interests of Indian states, will be inaugurated by Finance Minister K.N. Balagopal. Renowned economist M.A. Oommen will chair the inaugural session, while former Cabinet Secretary K.M. Chandrashekhar will deliver the keynote address. 

M. Govinda Rao, a member of the 14th Finance Commission, will be a special guest speaker. The seminar will be based on a report prepared by GIFT and will be chaired by K.N. Harilal, Chairman of the Kerala Finance Commission and President of KEA. 

The seminar will see prominent economists from various institutions and colleges in Kerala presenting their views on evolving fiscal federal relations in the country. Former Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac will be the chief guest at the valedictory function.

title: Muslim Jamaat Condemns Karnataka High Court Ruling on 'Jai Shri Ram' Slogans in Mosques
news:
The Kerala Muslim Jamaat has issued a strong condemnation of the Karnataka High Court's recent ruling, deeming it "unfortunate" and a potential threat to communal harmony. The court dismissed charges against two individuals who shouted "Jai Shri Ram" slogans inside a mosque, arguing that the act didn't constitute a disturbance of public order. 

The Jamaat, during its state cabinet meeting, expressed concerns that this ruling would embolden communal forces to challenge the sanctity of places of worship and ultimately endanger India's secular ethos. General Secretary Syed Ibrahim Khaleel Bukhari warned that allowing such actions would lead to further religious divisions and chaos. 

The Jamaat demanded the Karnataka government appeal the single-bench verdict, emphasizing India's historical respect for each other's religious spaces. The organization believes the ruling undermines the peaceful co-existence between religious communities.

title: Mumbai Police Detain Minor for Bomb Hoax Threats to Indian Airlines
news:
A 17-year-old teenager from Chhattisgarh has been detained by Mumbai Police for allegedly posting bomb threat messages on the social media handles of Indian Airlines. The arrest comes after a series of bomb threats caused widespread disruption to flights over the past few days.

The teenager, who is a 11th grade dropout and runs a small shop in Rajnandgaon, Chhattisgarh, is believed to have used a fake social media account to post the threats. Police suspect the motive behind the threats to be a financial dispute with another individual named Fazluddin Nirban, with whom the minor had a business disagreement. 

The threats resulted in delays and diversions of multiple flights, including IndiGo and Air India flights. The boy was apprehended after police traced the fake social media account and summoned him for questioning. He is currently in remand custody until October 24th. 

While the minor has been detained, Fazluddin Nirban was also arrested for questioning regarding the incident. 

This incident has sparked concerns over the growing number of bomb threats being made to Indian airlines. Police are continuing their investigation to ascertain if there are any links or patterns between the various threats.

title: Digital Transformation Takes Center Stage at ICA Asia Pacific Research Conference
news:
The 18th International Co-operative Alliance (ICA) Asia Pacific Research Conference, held in Kozhikode, India, saw experts advocating for the urgent adoption of digital transformation within the cooperative sector. 

The four-day event, jointly hosted by the ICA Asia Pacific, IIM-K, and the ULCCS, focused on the need for research and collaboration within cooperatives to ensure sustainable growth. 

Keynote speaker, former Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac, emphasized the importance of positioning Kerala as a leader in the knowledge-based economy under the Industry 5.0 framework. He highlighted the potential of cooperatives, with their strong community values, to lead this transition, particularly in a state with high unemployment amongst educated youth.

Balasubramanian Iyer, Regional Director of the ICA Asia-Pacific, stressed the vital role of knowledge-sharing amongst cooperatives worldwide. He underscored the organization's efforts in driving the global cooperative movement towards a sustainable and inclusive future.

A panel discussion, led by Prof. H.K. Misra, explored the readiness of Kerala's cooperatives for digital transformation.  While acknowledging the potential benefits, experts cautioned against centralized control and emphasized the need for a balanced approach to technology adoption.

Success stories from Self-Employed Women’s Association (SEWA) demonstrated the positive impact of digital initiatives in empowering women across India.  Despite challenges, SEWA's hybrid digital models have significantly enhanced economic inclusion for women in rural areas, showcasing a promising path for Kerala's cooperative sector.

title: AIUTUC Rallies for Workers' Rights Ahead of Mysuru Conference
news:
The All India United Trade Union Centre (AIUTUC) is holding its fourth State-level conference in Mysuru on October 26th and 27th. To raise awareness about the event and its goals, an awareness jatha (march) has been traversing the region, reaching Mysuru on Wednesday. The jatha will continue through Thursday, covering key roads and industrial areas in the city.

AIUTUC is using the conference to build a movement against what it sees as anti-worker policies from both the state and central governments. The union criticizes recent changes to labor laws, arguing that they prioritize corporate interests at the expense of workers' rights.  

AIUTUC's demands include:

* Permanent jobs for all with a guaranteed right to work.
* Abolition of the four new labor codes and strengthening of existing labor laws.
* A minimum monthly wage of ₹35,000.
* The withdrawal of GST on essential commodities.
* Regularization of contract worker positions and equal pay for equal work.
* Recognition of ASHA, Anganwadi, and Mid-day meal workers as government employees with a minimum wage of ₹35,000 and a monthly pension of ₹10,000.
* Withdrawal of the New Pension Scheme and reintroduction of the Old Pension Scheme.

The conference aims to bring together workers from across Karnataka to discuss these issues and strategize for future action.

title: Chennai Metro Rail's First Driverless Train Arrives for Extensive Testing
news:
Chennai Metro Rail's first driverless train, part of the ₹63,246 crore Phase II project, arrived in Chennai on October 17th, 2024. The three-coach train, manufactured in Sri City, underwent initial testing at the manufacturing center.  

Upon arrival at the Poonamallee depot, the train will undergo a comprehensive testing phase, including static and dynamic tests. This rigorous process will assess the functionality of brakes, heating, ventilation, air conditioning, lighting, circuits, pantograph, and other critical systems. The overhead electrical system will also be charged, and the train will be tested on a ballasted test track.

The driverless train is expected to carry approximately 1,000 commuters per trip. With the first service planned for next year between Poonamallee and Porur, more driverless trains are expected to arrive at the depot in the coming months for further testing.

title: Seven Killed, One Injured in Telangana Road Accident
news:
On Wednesday afternoon, a car accident in Medak district, Telangana, tragically claimed the lives of seven individuals, including three teenagers.  The vehicle, carrying close family members returning from a family function, crashed into a roadside tree before plunging into a canal. 

The victims, all residents of Shivampet, were identified as Danavath Shivaram (55), Danavath Durgi alias Durgamma (45), Maloth Anitha (30), Maloth Bindu (14), Maloth Sravani (12), Gugloth Shanthi (45), and Gugloth Mamatha (16). The driver, Gugloth Nam Singh (55), survived but is in critical condition.

Police investigations indicate the car was travelling at a high speed, lost control, and collided with the tree. The impact caused the car to fall into the canal, resulting in the drowning deaths. 

Chief Minister A. Revanth Reddy expressed his condolences and directed officials to provide necessary assistance to the injured and families of the deceased. State Minister for Medical, Health and Family Welfare Damodar Rajanarsimha also offered support, ordering the district administration and health department to provide immediate relief measures.
